audio_description: Biryani is a constant battle over whose biryani is the best. And not just that—how it's made too. In fact, every state, every community has its own version of biryani. So the one that's made at your home might not be the same as the one made at mine.

audio_description: But biryani is one such dish that, whenever it's made, fills the whole house with fragrance. And if you make a little extra, even the neighborhood will smell it. Today we are going to make Hyderabadi cooked meat (pakke gosht) biryani. We'll take the meat—

audio_description: I have this oil, in which I had fried the onions—this same oil will go in here. And now we’ll mix it all well. One special thing is, whenever we make Hyderabadi biryani, we never use kewra (screw pine essence) or rose water in it.

audio_description: And a sign of a good biryani—obviously—the rice shouldn’t be lumpy, shouldn't be undercooked. Each grain should be separate. That’s the hallmark of a great biryani, again and again.
